#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction
#Text=Along with the booming of mobile applications and the Internet of Things ( IoT ) , a momentously increasing number of mobile devices and applications are widely used at the network edge .
#Text=Based on a report from Cisco , it is predicted that around 850 ZB data will be generated at the network edge by 2021 , which significantly exceeds the traffic in global data centers .

#Text=Besides handling tremendous data , popular mobile applications and services , e. g. , video surveillance , interactive gaming , and voice assistants , require intensive computational resources .

#Text=In particular , with the proliferation of artificial intelligence ( AI ) supported smart applications , mobile and IoT devices face big challenges due to their limited computational capacities , as well as constrained power .
#Text=One of the conventional ways to deal with this issue is to offload the computation-intensive work and service data from mobile devices to remote cloud data centers .

#Text=However , moving from the network edge to remote cloud data centers via wide area networks ( WAN ) results in prohibitively high transmission latency and monetary cost , which is nontrivial especially for latency-sensitive applications .
#Text=Another major concern of processing data on remote clouds is the privacy leakage issue .
#Text=To fulfill the requirements of latency-sensitive and resource-intensive applications , the novel paradigm Multi-access Edge Computing ( MEC ) is proposed and promptly ascends to the spotlight .

#Text=By pushing computation tasks and data to small-sized cloudlets near mobile users , MEC reduces the transmission delay , alleviates the congestion in the network core , and saves the communication cost compared with remote cloud data centers .

#Text=As an essential component in the MEC paradigm , a cloudlet , which consists of trusted computers with rich resources , serves the last mile of the Internet as a complement to centralized remote clouds .
#Text=Despite the benefits of sinking the data and computation to the network edge , new concerns on the placement and capacity planning of cloudlets have risen .

#Text=It is not a trivial problem to balance the service performance and the infrastructure providers ’ ( ISP ) costs while additionally considering user mobility , cloudlets ’ coverage , and the large scale of Wireless Metropolitan Area Network ( WMAN ) .
#Text=Specifically , deploying more cloudlets closer to mobile users could reduce transmission delay and communication costs .
#Text=However , this will definitely add more costs of purchasing and operating physical servers .
#Text=Furthermore , to cope with user mobility , service migration has to be performed when a mobile user moves from the service region of one cloudlet to another .
#Text=Service migration ensures that users could seamlessly access network services , yet it poses additional migration costs and may suffer from handover failure .

#Text=Therefore , to deploy latency-sensitive and resource-intensive mobile services at network edge , one of the vital yet essential issues is to plan the cloudlets , including where to permanently place the cloudlets , what is the service region of each cloudlet , and how many physical resources should be assigned to each cloudlet considering the ISPs ’ cost and performance requirements by mobile users .
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=demonstrates an example of a cloudlet planning in a WMAN with multiple access point ( AP ) cells .
#Text=As shown in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=, each AP is covered by exactly one cloudlet and each cloudlet is co-existed with one AP in its service region .

#Text=However , most existing studies are limited to improving the Quality of Service ( QoS ) of mobile applications or services by properly offloading tasks to physically deployed cloudlets , e. g. , .
#Text=These studies focus on how the tasks or virtual services should be embedded in cloudlets that are equipped with virtualization techniques .
#Text=Obviously , the computational resources that could be assigned to each task or virtual service are bounded by the maximum available physical resources in each cloudlet .
#Text=In contrast , the planning of each cloudlet ’s physical location , capacity , and service region coverage has been ignored .
#Text=In our previous work , we noticed the impact of the cloudlet planning and started with an initial step of carefully partitioning the entire WMAN into disjoint service regions .
#Text=However , in only the minimization of service handover costs is discussed , while the cloudlet construction costs and operation costs are ignored .
#Text=Therefore , in the proposed solution , we only suggested the way to determine the service regions without the planning of cloudlets ’ physical placement and capacities .
